qas.question: Who was the traditional partner with Great Britain at the beginning of the conflict?

answers.text: Great Britain and Austria, had coalesced

qas.question: What was the major gain by Great Britain by having Austria as it ally?

answers.text: British subsidies to Austria had produced nothing of much help to the British

qas.question: What was gained or lost by Austria?

answers.text: British military effort had not saved Silesia for Austria

qas.question: Did the loss of Silesia by Austria intensify its battle with Prussia?

answers.text: . Prussia, having secured Silesia, had come to terms with Austria

qas.question: What alliances were formed in the "diplomatic reversal"?

answers.text: The collapse of that system and the aligning of France with Austria and of Great Britain with Prussia constituted what is known as the “diplomatic revolution”

context: The War of the Austrian Succession had seen the belligerents aligned on a time-honoured basis. France’s traditional enemies, <a0_0>Great Britain and Austria, had coalesced<a0_0/> just as they had done against Louis XIV. Prussia, the leading anti-Austrian state in Germany, had been supported by France. Neither group, however, found much reason to be satisfied with its partnership: <a1_0>British subsidies to Austria had produced nothing of much help to the British<a1_0/>, while the <a2_0>British military effort had not saved Silesia for Austria<a2_0/><a3_0>. Prussia, having secured Silesia, had come to terms with Austria<a3_0/> in disregard of French interests. Even so, France had concluded a defensive alliance with Prussia in 1747, and the maintenance of the Anglo-Austrian alignment after 1748 was deemed essential by the Duke of Newcastle, British secretary of state in the ministry of his brother Henry Pelham. <a4_0>The collapse of that system and the aligning of France with Austria and of Great Britain with Prussia constituted what is known as the “diplomatic revolution”<a4_0/> or the “reversal of alliances.”
